Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a corrective action plan is required. The corrective action

result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4126 Sufficiency of staff.
Section (1) The licensee shall have a sufficient number of administrative,
Description supervisory, social service, direct care, and other staff on duty to
perform the prescribed functions required by these administrative
rules and in the agency's program statement and to provide for the
continual needs, protection, and supervision of residents
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation While youth was placed at Wolverine Human Services, he was
being sexually abused.
Investigation Interviews:
On 05/22/2025 an email correspondence was sent to Foster Care
Worker 1 and Foster Care Worker 2. They were advised of the
special investigation involving Youth A and asked to respond with
any concerns involving Wolverine or the placement of Youth A at
the facility. No response was received.
On 05/22/2025 a telephone message was left for Complainant
requesting a return call with any additional concerns regarding
Youth A. It was reported that Youth A said someone touched him
and he didn’t even know he had been sexually abused until
another youth pointed it out to him. Complainant stated Youth A
did not report he was touched by a youth or a staff.
On 05/22/2025 an investigation was initiated on-site at Wolverine.
An interview was completed with Supervisor 1. She was advised
of the allegations. Supervisor 1 denied any knowledge of Youth A
reporting being sexually abused by staff or youth while at the
agency.
On 05/22/2025 a telephone call was made to Chief
Administrator (CA). A message was left advising that consultant
was onsite today to initiate Special Investigation. CA was asked
to return call to discuss allegations of special investigation. An
email was also sent to CA advising of special investigation
allegations and request was made for incident reports involving
Youth A and agency policy.
2

On 06/10/2025 a DHHS Dispositional Case Conference was held
via Teams Video to discuss case allegation and investigative
discoveries. DHHS has since advised there were no findings of
abuse or neglect.
On 06/12/2025 in-person interviews were completed at Wolverine.
DHHS Specialist 2 was also present. Staff 2, Therapist, Youth B
and Youth C were all interviewed in person. All denied any
knowledge of Youth A being sexually abused by youth or staff at
the agency. They all also denied knowledge of any sexual abuse
occurring at Wolverine.
On 06/26/2025 in-person interviews were completed at Wolverine.
DHHS Specialist 2 was also present. Staff 5, Staff 3, Youth D
and Youth G were all interviewed in person. All denied any
knowledge of Youth A being sexually abused by youth or staff at
the agency. They all also denied knowledge of any sexual abuse
occurring at Wolverine.
Documents Reviewed:
DHHS Specialist 1 Social Work Contact:
Contact dated 06/04/2025. DHHS Specialist spoke with Youth H
at Wolverine. Youth H reported he has never seen staff talk or act
sexually inappropriately to the children at Wolverine.
Contact dated 06/23/2025. DHHS Specialist spoke with Staff 6.
He recalled Youth A but denied knowledge of youth being sexually
abused. He denied ever seeing or hearing of Youth A being
sexually abused by staff or youth.
DHHS Specialist 3 Social Work Contact:
Contact dated 06/05/2025. Interview of Youth A – Contact
indicated Youth A denied any kind of sexual assault or abuse by
staff or youth when he was placed at Wolverine. He reported he
was not aware of any sexual abuse happening to anyone while he
was there. Youth A stated if it had happened to him "he would be
telling everybody". Youth A also expressed that while placed at
Wolverine Staff would let youth do whatever they wanted, not
providing supervision and that some did not care if kids were
fighting. These allegations were being investigated as a part of
2025SIC0000691. There were no findings of non-compliance.
Wolverine Human Services Employee Standard of Conduct
Policy: All employees of WHS are expected to conduct
themselves in accordance with the agencies principles and
values. By accepting employment with WHS, staff have a
3

responsibility to WHS clients, their families, the agency, Michigan
and federal law, and to fellow employees to adhere to certain
standards of conduct and ethics. The following are prohibited
client interventions: 2. WHS has a zero tolerance for rape, sexual
abuse, sexual harassment and threats to clients. The above
interactions constitute violation of client rights and will not be
tolerated.
Incident Reports:
Incident report: 03/23/25
Summary: Youth A tried to hit another youth. No injuries were
noted.
Behavior notification report: 03/07/25
Summary: Youth A became aggressive with staff at an Urgent
Care over wanting to make a phone call. Staff was able to return
Youth A to baseline.
Behavior notification: 03/30/25
Summary: Another youth physically assaulted Youth A.
There were no noted injuries.
Behavior notification: 03/03/25
Summary: Resident woke up at 3:10am worried about clients
trying to fight him. Client attempted to make weapons from
pencils. Client returned to baseline.
Video Footage Review:
Wolverine facility has cameras in common areas and hallways.
There are no timeframes or area identified where this incident may
have occurred to be able to obtain any video footage. There was
no recording known by Chief Administrator or Supervisor1
supporting the allegations.
Analysis At the conclusion of the investigation, the agency was found to be
in compliance with the licensing rule. Both staff and youth were
interviewed and there was not sufficient evidence to support non-
compliance with the licensing rule. Youth A denied being touched
inappropriately by staff and Staff 1 denied
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109 Program statement
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
Description statement which specifically addresses all of the following: (c)
Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care, safety, and
4

supervision, methods for addressing residents' needs,
implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of residents.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Staff was sleeping while at work.
Investigation Interviews:
Staff 2 was interviewed on 6/12/2025 at Wolverine. DHHS
Specialist 2 was also present. Staff 2 denied knowledge of staff
sleeping on the job at the agency.
Therapist was interviewed at Wolverine on 6/12/2025. DHHS
Specialist 2 was also present. He denied that youth have reported
concerns to him about staff sleeping at work. Therapist also
denied personal knowledge of staff sleeping on the job.
On 6/12/2025, Youth C was interviewed at Wolverine. DHHS
Specialist 2 was also present. He denied seeing staff sleep while
at work since he was placed eight days ago.
On 06/13/2025 I participated in an interview with Youth B via
telephone. DHHS Specialist was present in person with Youth B.
He recalled his placement at Wolverine. Youth B stated that he
did not “remember anything” that happened at Wolverine. He
denied ever seeing staff sleep at Wolverine. He said that
sometimes staff would close their eyes but would not sleep.
Youth B stated he knew they were not asleep as they would still
be talking. Youth B was not able to provide the identify of staff that
he witnessed with their eyes closed. When attempting to verify
details of his statement, Youth B continued to state he did not
“remember anything” that happened when he was at Wolverine.
On 06/26/2025 an in-person interview was completed with Youth
D at Wolverine. DHHS Specialist was also present. He reported
that Staff 4 sleeps at work. He reported seeing her sleep at work
about a couple of weeks ago during second shift. He reported he
only saw her once, but knows she sleeps at work all the time. He
was unable to state how he knows she sleeps at work all the time.
On 06/26/2025 an in-person interview was held with Staff 5 and
Staff 3 at Wolverine. DHHS Specialist was also present. Both
denied having knowledge of or seeing Staff 4 sleeping at work.
They both also denied seeing other staff sleep at work.
5

On 06/26/2025 an in-person interview was held with Youth G at
Wolverine. DHHS Specialist was also present. He reported
seeing Staff 4 sleeping at work about one or two weeks ago. He
did not recall who else was around at the time. He stated that it
was during second shift and they were on the second floor of the
agency.
On 07/02/2025 a telephone interview was completed with Staff 4.
She confirmed she has fallen asleep at work before and reported
that she believes she received some type of discipline. She was
unable to advise the type or level of discipline received.
On 07/28/2025 a video interview was completed with Youth A.
He reported that he has witnessed staff sleeping while at work.
He identified Staff 2 as a staff person that he has seen sleep at
work. Youth A said that other staff would sleep also, but could not
recall names of those staff. He reported staff would be asleep
during their shift and would fall asleep about 20 minutes after
arriving at work. He reported other staff were “just walking
around, doing nothing”. He confirmed that other youth were
around and would see staff sleeping. He was able to recall one
youth by name, Youth D, but did not provide additional names.
When asked how he knew that the staff were sleeping, Youth A
replied, “I just know”.
Documents Reviewed:
Wolverine Human Services Employee Standard of Conduct
Policy: All employees of WHS are expected to conduct
themselves in accordance with the agencies principles and
values. By accepting employment with WHS, staff have a
responsibility to WHS clients, their families, the agency, Michigan
and federal law, and to fellow employees to adhere to certain
standards of conduct and ethics. The following are prohibited
client interventions: Sleeping on the job.
Wolverine Human Services Employee Counseling Form: Issued to
Staff 4 and Dated 6/06/2025. Form indicated employee received
a three-day suspension as a result of insubordination, violation of
safety rules, violation of company rules and unsatisfactory work
performance. It further indicated that Staff 4 was observed
sleeping at work on 6/06/2025.
Analysis At the conclusion of the investigation, the agency was found to be
in non-compliance with the licensing rule. The youth reported
witnessing Staff 4 sleeping at work and Staff 4 admitted to
sleeping at work.
6

Conclusion Repeat Violation Established

Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158 Intervention standards and prohibitions
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention: (a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not
limited to: (ii) Hitting or striking, throwing, kicking, pulling, or
pushing a youth on any part of their body.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Staff punched Youth B in the chest twice.
Investigation Interviews:
On 06/12/2025 a voicemail message was left for Complainant
requesting a return call with any additional concerns. No return
call was received.
Staff 2 was interviewed on 6/12/2025 at Wolverine. DHHS
Specialist 2 was also present. Staff 2 denied any disciplinary
action in his file. Staff 2 recalled both Youth A and Youth B. He
denied ever hitting Youth B or any other youth at the agency.
Staff 2 described himself as a staff member that worked hard to
keep the peace at the agency. He further highlighted that his own
history of trauma and growing up in foster care provides him with
a different approach and/or view in working with the youth. Staff 2
denied use of physical discipline with youth at the agency. He
recalled that Youth B was mostly on the 3rd floor. He stated he
worked on all floors in the agency, but had minimal contact with
Youth B.
Therapist was interviewed at Wolverine on 6/12/2025. DHHS
Specialist 2 was also present. He reported he was the therapist
for Youth A, Youth B and Youth D. He denied any of the youth
reported to him concerns of staff being physically aggressive or
punching them. Therapist specifically denied any reports from
Youth B or Youth D about concerns with Staff 2. He advised that
most of the youth like Staff 2 and he has never had any reports of
concern regarding Staff 2 being physically aggressive.
7

On 6/12/2025, Youth C was interviewed at Wolverine. DHHS
Specialist 2 was also present. Youth reported feeling safe at the
agency. He has been at Wolverine for about 8 days. He advised
that Staff 2 is his favorite staff and is always available when he
needs or wants to talk. He denied knowledge of any staff being
physically aggressive with youth.
On 6/12/2025 the safety plan for Staff 2 was reviewed by the
DHHS Specialist 2, myself and Program Manager. It was agreed
that Staff 2 would be shadowed at work by another staff and
immediate intervention would occur if he was found to be
inappropriate or acting outside of policy guidelines with youth.
On 06/13/2025 I participated in an interview with Youth B via
telephone. DHHS Specialist 4 was present in person with Youth
B. He recalled his placement at Wolverine but denied knowing
Staff 2. Youth B stated that he did not “remember anything” that
happened at Wolverine. He denied seeing staff at Wolverine
being physically or verbally aggressive with youth. He denied that
he was ever restrained at Wolverine. Youth B reported feeling
safe at Wolverine and said nothing happened to him there, but
something did happen to him at another agency. He stated in
November when he was placed at another agency, he had his
head pushed on a metal bed frame by two staff. He further stated
he was injured and did not receive medical attention. This
allegation is being addressed via SI# 2025SIC0000796.
On 06/17/2025 an email correspondence was sent to Foster Care
Worker 3 (FCW3), the assigned worker for Youth B. FCW3 was
advised of the allegations, and a response was requested
regarding any concerns with the placement of the youth at the
facility. No response was received.
On 06/26/2025 an in-person interview was completed with Youth
D at Wolverine. DHHS Specialist 2 was also present. He
reported feeling safe at the facility. He denied knowledge of or
seeing Staff 2 being physically aggressive with youth and
specifically denied knowledge of Staff 2 hitting Youth A or Youth
B. Youth D further denied that any youth at the facility ever told
him that Staff 2 hit them. Youth D stated that the “kids be lying to
get people in trouble”. Lastly, Youth D denied that staff ever hit
him.
On 06/26/2025 an in-person interview was completed with Staff 5
at Wolverine. DHHS Specialist 2 was also present. Staff 5 denied
8

seeing Staff 2 hit any youth. He denied witnessing a physical
altercation between Youth B and Staff 2.
On 06/26/2025 an in-person interview was completed with Staff 3
at Wolverine. DHHS Specialist 2 was also present. Staff 3 denied
knowledge of or seeing Staff 2 punching a youth at the facility. He
recalled that Youth B had a problem with authority and as a result
did not follow directives provided by staff. Staff 3 denied seeing a
physical altercation between Youth B and Staff 2. He added that
most youth at Wolverine love Staff 2 and that Staff 2 has a
positive way to engage with the youth.
On 07/28/2025 a video interview was completed with Youth A. He
He reported that Youth B told him that Staff 2 punched him, but
Youth A denied seeing Staff 2 punch or hit Youth B.
Documents Reviewed:
Wolverine Human Services Behavior Management Policy: All
staff are to be certified in Crisis Prevention Institute Non-Violent
Crisis Intervention. Non-violent physical restrictions are only to be
used to protect clients or others from unanticipated or severely
aggressive behavior that places them at risk of violence or injury if
no intervention occurs. Interventions must be guided by a number
of factors, including safety of other clients and staff, size and
strength of client, degree of past violent behavior, whether the
client has a weapon, physical or health conditions of the client,
client's Individual Crisis Management Plan. Post-incident
debriefing must also occur.
Wolverine Human Services Employee Standard of Conduct
Policy: All employees of WHS are expected to conduct
themselves in accordance with the agency’s principles and values.
By accepting employment with WHS, staff have a responsibility to
WHS clients, their families, the agency, Michigan and federal law,
and to fellow employees to adhere to certain standards of conduct
and ethics. The following are prohibited client interventions:
1. Use of physical discipline inflicted in any manner.
Incident Reports:
There were no incident reports related to these allegations.
Video Footage:
There was no video footage related to allegations.
Tour of agency:
9

A tour of the agency was completed on June 12, 2025. There
were no areas of concern noted.
Analysis At the conclusion of the investigation, the agency was found to be
in compliance with the licensing rule. Both staff and youth were
interviewed and there was no evidence to support non-compliance
with the licensing rule.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158 Intervention standards and prohibitions
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention: (a) Any type of physical punishment including but not
limited to: (iv) Verbal abuse including the use of derogatory or
discriminatory language including negative references to a youth’s
background or appearance or mental state. Yelling, threats,
ridicule, or humiliation are strictly prohibited.

denied threatening Youth A or any other youth at the agency.
Therapist was interviewed at Wolverine on 6/12/2025. DHHS

On 6/12/2025, Youth C was interviewed at Wolverine. DHHS

threatening to hit youth.
On 06/13/2025 I participated in an interview with Youth B via
telephone. DHHS Specialist 4 was present in person with Youth
10

Staff 2. Youth B stated that he did not “remember anything” that
happened at Wolverine. He denied seeing or hearing staff at

On 06/26/2025 an in-person interview was completed with Youth
D at Wolverine. DHHS Specialist 2 was also present. He denied
knowledge of Staff 2 threatening Youth A or Youth B. Youth D
further denied that any youth at the facility ever told him that Staff

On 06/26/2025 an in-person interview was completed with Staff 5
at Wolverine. DHHS Specialist 2 was also present. Staff 5 denied

On 06/26/2025 an in-person interview was completed with Staff 3
at Wolverine. DHHS Specialist 2 was also present. Staff 3 denied

facility.
On 7/28/2025 a video interview was completed with Youth A. He
reported that Staff 2 threatened to punch him in his stomach “like
his dad used to do”. Youth A denied that Staff 2 ever punched
him, but again confirmed that the threat was made. Youth A
recalled Staff 2 only threatening him on one occasion.
Documents Reviewed:
DHHS Specialist 3 Social Work Contact: Dated 06/05/2025
Interview of Youth A – Contact indicated Youth A reported that

Analysis At the conclusion of the investigation, the agency was found to be

Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. A corrective action plan is required.
